question: Question_03_(d)
hints:
Note that this improper integral has \textbf{both} upper and lower
limits of integration being improper.

To write it as a standard Type I improper integral, one first has to
split it into two integrals. Then, if both integrals converge, the
original integral converges. But if at least one of the integrals
diverges, then the original integral diverges.

Since this is a an improper integral, you can \textbf{not} argue that
the integral should be zero (and hence converge) because the integrand
is an odd function. Such an argument is only valid for proper integrals.
